title: 112_hr2790
content:
The Act titled "Child and Family Services Extension and Enhancement Act" extends the Stephanie Tubbs Jones Child Welfare Services Program. The Child and Family Services Extension and Enhancement Act amends Section 425 of the Social Security Act to cover the years 2012 through 2016. It also modifies certain state plan requirements related to emotional trauma, psychotropic medications, and developmental needs of young children. The Child and Family Services Extension and Enhancement Act amends Section 425 of the Social Security Act to cover the years 2012 through 2016. It also modifies state plan requirements related to reducing the time children without a permanent family placement and addressing the developmental needs of young children receiving benefits. Additionally, it revises child visitation by caseworkers under Section 424 of the Act. Each State must ensure that caseworkers visit children in foster care at least 90% of the time each month. If a State fails to meet this requirement, the percentage for federal funding purposes will be reduced. Each State must ensure that not less than 50 percent of caseworker visits to children in foster care occur in the child's residence. If a State fails to meet this requirement, the federal funding percentage will be reduced by 1 if the shortfall is less than 10 percentage points, or by 5 if the shortfall is 20 or more percentage points. In section 423(b) of the Act, the term "per centum" is corrected to "percent". The federal funding percentage reduction for States failing to meet the caseworker visit requirement is 1 if the shortfall is less than 10 percentage points, 3 if it's between 10 and 20 points, and 5 if it's 20 or more points. SEC. 3. Extension of program to promote safe and stable families. Section 436 of the Social Security Act is amended to allocate $345,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2016. Additionally, Section 437 is amended to provide $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2016 for discretionary and targeted grants. Section 438 of the Social Security Act is amended to update funding allocations for state courts handling proceedings related to foster care and adoption from 2012 to 2016. This includes requirements for concurrent planning and the ability to bypass reunification efforts in certain situations. This includes requirements for concurrent planning and the ability to bypass reunification efforts in certain situations. Amendments include changes to the amount reserved for grants and the submission of State Summaries of Financial Data to Congress and publication on the HHS website. The amendment to Section 438 of the Social Security Act requires annual submission of State Reports to Congress, including planned and actual spending by service category for foster care and adoption programs. The Secretary must publish the compilation on the HHS website by September 30 each year for public accessibility. The Department of Health and Human Services website is easily accessible to the public. Section 437(f) of the Act is amended to eliminate references to methamphetamines in substance abuse grants. Section 439 of the Act (42 U.S.C. 629i) is amended to authorize grants for mentoring programs for children of prisoners in areas with substantial numbers of incarcerated parents. The purpose is to support the establishment or expansion of programs providing mentoring services through a network of public and private community entities. Section 439 of the Act is amended to authorize grants for mentoring programs for children of prisoners in areas with substantial numbers of incarcerated parents. The amendments include changes to subsections (h) and (g), updating the fiscal years and removing references to specific projects. Section 439 of the Act is amended to authorize grants for mentoring programs for children of prisoners in areas with substantial numbers of incarcerated parents. The evaluation of the demonstration project is updated with changes to subsections (h) and (g), including adjustments to funding for fiscal years. Section 439 of the Act is amended to authorize grants for mentoring programs for children of prisoners in areas with substantial numbers of incarcerated parents. Technical corrections are made to sections of the Social Security Act regarding forms and benefits. In section 8(b) of the Act, an amendment replaces the reference to 438(b) with 438(b)(1) of the same Act. SEC. 440 of the Social Security Act introduces data standardization for improved data matching. The Secretary, in consultation with an interagency work group, designates nonproprietary and interoperable standard data elements for reported information under this part, incorporating interoperable standards from international consensus bodies. The Secretary, in consultation with an interagency work group, designates nonproprietary and interoperable standard data elements for reported information under this part, incorporating standards from international consensus bodies such as the International Organization for Standardization and the National Information Exchange Model. Federal entities also develop and maintain interoperable standards for contracting and financial assistance, as governed by the Federal Acquisition Regulations Council. The Secretary shall designate data reporting standards for this part, incorporating nonproprietary formats, applicable accounting principles, and upgradable capabilities. Existing nonproprietary standards like the eXtensible Business Reporting Language should be included. The amendment made by subsection (a) will be effective on October 1, 2012, applying to information required to be reported on or after that date. SEC. 5. PROVISIONS RELATING TO FOSTER CARE OR ADOPTION. (a) Educational Stability for Each Foster Placement.--Section 475(1)(G) of the Social Security Act is amended to ensure stability in each placement. 
(b) Study on Recruitment of and Support for Foster Parents, Adoptive Parents, and Kin Guardians.--The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on supporting families caring for children in foster care, adoption, and kinship guardianship programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on foster parents, respite care, capacity of service providers, barriers to recruiting and retaining foster families, barriers to supporting adoptive parents and relative caregivers, and any other relevant matters. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on foster parents, respite care, service provider capacity, barriers to recruiting and retaining foster families, supporting adoptive parents and relative caregivers, and other relevant matters. Within 3 years, a report with findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress. Adoption spending documentation requirements will be amended. The effective date for the provisions outlined in the previous paragraphs will be specified. The Act and its amendments will take effect on October 1, 2011, applying to payments under specific parts of the Social Security Act. If State legislation is needed for compliance, a delay is permitted. States must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the first regular session of the State legislature following the enactment of the Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
